channel.title: My new car
channel.description:
Ive just bought a new car. Its a 2005 Honda Accord LX. I cant post pictures now because its night...but when I get a chance I will. This picture is exactally what it looks like from the back its the same color. Its only a Inline 4 cyclinder but Im only using it to drive too and from school so what do you think? Im swapping the current radio with a nav from ebay.
[img]http://www.edmunds.com/media/roadtests/comparison/2004/04.family.sedan/honda.accord/04.honda.accord.r34.500.jpg[/img]

item.title: My new car
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

[quote=“Waffendennis, post:25, topic:297099”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=393119.msg2952786#msg2952786 date=1252635918]

VTEC should engage at 6000 RPM

Damn, what is the redline on those? Most of my cars redline at about 4000-5000 RPMs, with all the power at much lower RPMs. No wonder the engines don’t last that long spinning so damn fast.
[/quote]

Redline starts at 7400 rpm. Thats the difference between 4 cylinder and 8 cylinders with more capacity. The 8 cylinder big blocks have their volume with them, so they don’t need to rev much to make power.

The engine from the Honda Integra Type-R is a 4 cylinder 1.8 liter. VTEC engages at 5800 RPM… But the redline starts at 9000 RPM and it’s balanced and built to handle up to 10.500 RPM.
It produces 220 HP out of the factory.[/quote]

Read full topic

[/quote]

Damn, what is the redline on those? Most of my cars redline at about 4000-5000 RPMs, with all the power at much lower RPMs. No wonder the engines don’t last that long spinning so damn fast.[/quote]

Redline starts at 7400 rpm. Thats the difference between 4 cylinder and 8 cylinders with more capacity. The 8 cylinder big blocks have their volume with them, so they don’t need to rev much to make power.

The engine from the Honda Integra Type-R is a 4 cylinder 1.8 liter. VTEC engages at 5800 RPM… But the redline starts at 9000 RPM and it’s balanced and built to handle up to 10.500 RPM.
It produces 220 HP out of the factory.

item.title: My new car
item.dc:creator: @Waffendennis Waffendennis
item.description:
@Waffendennis wrote:

Word of advice.

Replace the standard intake with an Password JDM coolchamber or a Mugen Airbox.
It will give a very nice sound, performance upgrade and you get a better MPG result.

item.title: My new car
item.dc:creator: @Waffendennis Waffendennis
item.description:
@Waffendennis wrote:

[quote=“mwiebelhaus, post:7, topic:297099”][quote author=Waffendennis link=topic=393119.msg2926283#msg2926283 date=1251023415]
Nice choise! You can’t go wrong with Honda :D! I don’t like the colour tho, it should’ve been blue or black.
What engine is in it, the 1.8, 2.0 or 2.2?
[/quote]

Its a i-Vtech 2.4l DOHC or that is at least what it says when I pop the hood.[/quote]

Nice, thats a K24a3 with 190hp. VTEC should engage at 6000 RPM (you should hear an audible difference and feel more power).

Read full topic

item.title: My new car
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“chrisn2323, post:19, topic:297099”]http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/V4_engine

they exist[/quote]

Saab featured the Ford 1,500 cc (92 cu in) OHV V4 engine in their 95, 96 and Sonett models, producing 65 bhp (48 kW) and 85 lb·ft (115 N·m) of torque.

Wow! What a beast! That is about the kind of power current Japanese engines put out.

Read full topic

item.title: My new car
item.dc:creator: @chrisn2323 chrisn2323
item.description:
@chrisn2323 wrote:

en.wikipedia.org

V4 engine

A V4 engine is a four-cylinder engine with its cylinders arranged in a "V" configuration. The V4 configuration has seen use in automobiles, motorcycles, marine propulsion, and for industrial/commercial applications. Conceptually, a V4 is a pair of V-twin engines mounted end-to-end. Most V4 designs support the crankshaft with three main bearings and have two crankpins that are shared by opposing cylinders. Odd-numbered cylinders are usually in one bank and even-numbered cylinders in the opposite...

they exist

Read full topic
